summary: A video tutorial demonstrating techniques to break up tiling textures in Unreal Engine 5, presented by Shane Whittington.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a title screen displaying the text "BREAK UP TILING TEXTURES IN UNREAL ENGINE 5" against a background divided into red, blue, and yellow sections. The scene transitions to a first-person view of a virtual environment, showcasing a rocky landscape with a stream and autumn foliage. Two yellow rectangles highlight areas of the terrain, emphasizing the tiling textures. The video then shifts to a comparison of textures, showing a "Bad Texture" with visible tiling lines on the left and a "Seamless Texture" on the right, both labeled accordingly. The comparison continues with the addition of "MicroVariation" and "MacroVariationNoise" textures, illustrating the differences in texture quality and detail. Throughout the video, the text "Shane Whittington" appears at the bottom, along with a note about a voice issue due to COVID-19. The video effectively demonstrates the visual impact of texture tiling and the benefits of seamless and varied textures in Unreal Engine 5.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a calm, conversational male voice introducing the topic of tiling textures in game art and the negative effect of poorly executed textures, asserting the listener is a "good game artist." The speaker declares that he will provide "four pro techniques for breaking up the tiling" of textures to avoid undesirable results. Music then begins, of a somewhat synthesized, electronic style with a neutral tone, and continues as the speaker ends with "stick around to the end."

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a detailed process of creating a grass texture in a 3D modeling software. Initially, the software interface displays a green textured plane labeled "Bad Texture" against a blue background, with various tools and settings visible on the right side. The user navigates through the software, opening a folder named "BreakfastBaking" and selecting a green sphere and a grass texture image. The scene transitions to a Google search for grass textures, highlighting various options and a detailed view of a grass texture image. The user then returns to the software, importing the grass texture image and adjusting settings within the material graph, including the "Vector Noise" and "Vector Lerp" nodes. The video concludes with the user applying the grass texture to a sphere, demonstrating the final result of the texture application. Throughout the video, the user's actions are focused on refining and applying the grass texture, with the software interface providing tools and settings to achieve the desired visual effect.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining that textures can look tiled and how to check if the texture is seamless. The speaker elaborates on what seamless means with a neutral, instructional tone. The speaker points out the texture shown isn't seamless, and the speaker's tone suggests dissatisfaction. Later the speaker explains that they will replace the texture with a seamless texture to show the difference it can make. The male speaker lists the steps of importing textures and creating a new material in a neutral and informative tone. The male speaker describes the components of the material. The male speaker mentions the similarity of the material to the texture which isn't seamless, ending with the speaker explaining that using good seamless textures makes a difference.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a 3D modeling software interface, focusing on the creation and editing of textures for a grassy terrain. Initially, two textures are displayed side by side: a "Bad Texture" with a repetitive, grid-like pattern and a "Seamless Texture" with a more natural, uniform appearance. The interface includes various panels and tools for manipulating the textures, such as a content browser, settings, and a material graph. The user interacts with the software, adjusting settings and exploring different texture options. The scene transitions to a detailed view of the material graph, where the user connects nodes to create a seamless grass texture. The interface highlights the process of selecting and applying textures, with a focus on the "GrassMicroVariation" material. The video concludes with the user finalizing the texture setup, demonstrating the seamless integration of textures into the 3D environment. Throughout the video, the interface remains consistent, with a dark theme and various tools and panels visible, emphasizing the software's functionality for texture creation and editing.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker noting something "already looks way better than the original." He proceeds in an instructional tone, explaining how to add micro variation to a material. Specifically, he mentions the ability to tile a texture by different amounts, using a "texture coordinate node" and multiplying it by a scalar parameter. He sets the default value to "0.5," stating that it gives a better result.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a 3D modeling software interface, specifically focusing on the material graph editor. The interface is dark-themed, with various nodes and connections visible, indicating the creation or editing of a material. The user is interacting with the material graph, adding and connecting nodes to create a material. The nodes include color inputs, texture maps, and other material properties. The user is seen adjusting settings and parameters within the nodes, such as color values and texture coordinates. The right side of the screen displays a material properties panel, where the user can further customize the material's appearance. Throughout the video, the user is actively working on the material graph, making adjustments and refining the material's properties to achieve the desired look for the textured sphere. The overall atmosphere is one of focused work on 3D modeling and material design.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker, in a casual and instructional tone, describes adding a tint to the color within a texturing software, specifying a vector parameter and the adjustment of default colors. He mentions copying, pasting, renaming parameters, and the alteration of default values. The speaker describes changing the name of the vector parameter to micro-variation tint, and then the use of the green channel of the grass texture, and eventually changes the value of micro-variation tint to a pale yellow color.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a 3D modeling software interface, specifically focusing on the material graph editor. The interface is dark-themed, with various nodes and connections visible, indicating the creation or editing of a material. On the left side of the screen, there is a preview window showing a textured sphere, resembling grass, which is likely the object being worked on. The user interacts with the material graph by dragging and dropping nodes, connecting them, and adjusting settings. The nodes include color swatches, texture maps, and other material properties. events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker describing the need for a blending technique between micro color and its variations. He explains creating a new texture sample using T_macro variation from Unreal Engine's starter content, and using a texture coordinate node multiplied by a scalar for tiling control. He then sets a default value for micro variation alpha tiling. The speaker continues by describing creating a linear interpolate node, and using the red channel of the micro variation blend.

events_list.video_caption:
The video showcases a detailed process of creating and editing a grass texture within a 3D modeling software interface. Initially, the interface displays a node-based material graph with various nodes connected by lines, indicating the flow of data and operations. The nodes are labeled with terms such as "GrassMicroVariation," "Material Graph," and "Color," suggesting the creation of a material with specific properties. A 3D model of a grassy sphere is visible on the left side of the screen, providing a visual reference for the material being created. The user interacts with the nodes, adjusting settings and connections to refine the material's appearance.

As the video progresses, the user applies a shader to the material, as indicated by a tooltip message stating, "Apply Shader to generate a material and make it the new one." This action is followed by a transition to a 3D viewport where two textures are displayed side by side: "Seamless Texture" and "MicroVariation." The "Seamless Texture" appears as a uniform green surface, while the "MicroVariation" texture shows a more detailed, natural grass appearance. The user then opens a color picker tool, selecting a color for the material, which is reflected in the 3D model of the grassy sphere.

Throughout the video, the interface remains consistent, with various toolbars and panels visible, including options for adjusting texture settings, adding effects, and managing objects within the scene. The user's actions are focused on refining the material's properties to achieve a realistic grass texture, as evidenced by the detailed adjustments made to the node-based graph and the final appearance of the 3D model. The video concludes with the user continuing to fine-tune the material, ensuring the desired visual outcome is achieved.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker outlining steps in a process. He plans to "set the result of our microcolor to A," then "the result of our microcolor variation to B," and finally "plug it into our base color." He speaks in an instructional and straightforward tone. He then says that he will save it and check out the results. He describes how the tiling is broken up by the difference between the two variations. He notes that he can also change the color of the tints to keep the transition from being too jarring.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a detailed process of creating a textured surface within a 3D modeling software interface. Initially, the interface displays a split-screen view with two textures labeled "Seamless Textures" and "MicroVariation," both featuring a green grass-like pattern. The right side of the screen shows a list of settings and options for the "MicroVariation" texture, including parameters like "World Size" and "Seed." The user navigates through the software, selecting different textures and adjusting settings, as indicated by the changing thumbnails and settings on the right side of the screen. The focus then shifts to a "Material Graph" window, where the user interacts with various nodes and connections, such as "Noise" and "MicroVariation," to modify the texture's appearance. The left side of the screen displays a preview of the textured sphere, showing the effects of the adjustments made in the material graph. The user continues to refine the texture by adjusting parameters like "Noise Control" and "Seed," with the preview updating in real-time to reflect these changes. The video concludes with a view of the final textured surface, now labeled "MicroVariationNoiseMap," displayed on a split-screen view alongside the original textures, highlighting the enhanced detail and variation achieved through the material graph adjustments. Throughout the video, the interface remains consistent, with various tools and settings visible, emphasizing the software's capabilities for creating and manipulating textures in 3D modeling.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker in a conversational tone, stating that "this looks better again." He mentions remembering to set a default tiling value and speaks about breaking up the tiling further. He plans to add some noise to the material in the form of darker patches of grass. He describes his steps, mentioning creating another texture sample and using the T_macro variation, copying and pasting it. He talks about putting it in a texture coordinate node, multiplying it by a constant value. He describes controlling the brightness of textures, adding 0.5 to the red channel and multiplying the results. He mentions adding it all into a comment named "macro variation noise." He describes giving himself control over the contrast of the noise by creating a scalar parameter called "noise contrast." He sets a default value to 0.5, plugs it into the A input of a lerp, leaving B set to 1. He plugs his macro variation noise into the alpha of the lerp and multiplies the result by everything already going into the base color. He plans to take a look at the result and compare it to previous work, noting the difference and planning to match the tint colors. He ends by explaining the effect of macro variation noise, especially when changing the noise contrast parameter.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a 3D modeling software interface, where a user is working on a grassy terrain. The interface displays various panels, including a 'Content Browser' with assets like 'MacroVariation' and 'MacroVariationController,' and a 'Details' panel with settings for 'Global Surface Parameter' and 'Global Vector Parameter.' The main viewport shows a split-screen view of the terrain, with a cursor positioned in the center. The user adjusts the terrain's texture and settings, as indicated by the changes in the 'Details' panel. The scene transitions to a zoomed-out view of the terrain, revealing a larger landscape with a smooth, grassy surface and a clear blue sky. The user continues to manipulate the terrain, adjusting its parameters and observing the changes in the viewport. The video concludes with the terrain appearing more refined, with a consistent grass texture and a seamless landscape.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker noting that "it's almost impossible to tell" that the material is made up of the same tiling texture. He continues, stating that, despite all the variation added to the material, the textures still look tiled on larger environments. The speaker mentions creating a long strip of landscape to illustrate the point. The speaker's tone throughout is informative.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a detailed process of creating a material in a 3D modeling software. It begins with a view of a 3D landscape featuring a grassy terrain and a body of water, with the software's interface visible, including a content browser and a material editor. The focus then shifts to the material editor, where a complex node-based material graph is displayed, with various nodes connected to create a material for a spherical object resembling a planet. The nodes include textures, color adjustments, and other material properties, with the interface showing options for editing and previewing the material. The video progresses through different stages of the material creation process, highlighting the addition and adjustment of nodes, such as 'MicroColorOverwrite' and 'MicroColorOverwrite2', to refine the material's appearance. The interface also displays a preview of the material applied to the spherical object, which appears to be a textured, greenish planet. The video concludes with a detailed view of the material graph, showing the intricate connections and adjustments made to achieve the desired material properties. Throughout the video, the software's interface remains consistent, with various tools and options available for editing and previewing the material.
events_list.audio_caption: A single male speaker explains how to solve an issue by making the tiling of the material change when it’s further away from the camera. He says, "I'll go back into my material one final time," and describes how to select various groups, rename them, and replace parameters. Then, he discusses replacing the scale parameter and setting default values for the tint and variation tint. He says, "Next I created alert and connected everything." The speaker continues, talking about the need to show textures up close and blend them smoothly, detailing the creation of pixel depth and subtract nodes. He then creates a scalar and moves on to creating a divide and a clamp. Concluding, he says, "I'll stick this into a comment," and explains what this does as he applies the material to the other landscape.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a 3D modeling software interface, where a user is working on a landscape scene featuring a grassy terrain with a snow-covered area. The interface displays various panels, including a content browser, a material graph, and a settings panel. The user is seen adjusting the material properties of the terrain, with a focus on the snow texture. The material graph shows a complex network of nodes, indicating the use of multiple textures and settings to achieve the desired look. The user interacts with the interface, selecting and modifying materials, and the scene is updated in real-time to reflect these changes. The video highlights the process of creating and refining a realistic landscape within the software, with a particular emphasis on the snow texture and its integration into the overall scene.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with one male speaker explaining that "close to the camera, the color is black, further away it's white" and that there's a "smooth gradient fading between the two colors". He then details how black will be near textures, while white will be far textures, before outlining the process of setting up the material. The speaker then states he will create a new lerp and then explains he'll take the result of the lerp from the near group and plug this into A, the lerp from the far group and plug this into B and lastly taking the result of the "Create Gradient Far From Camera" group and plugging this into the Alpha. Then, the speaker plans to place the result of the lerp in the B input of the multiply to add noise before saving the material, creating an instance, and applying it to the second landscape. The speaker ends the clip detailing matching colors for the tints and using the material instance to alter values for parameters to achieve a desired result.
